review_title: Could be brilliant but ruined by upper management
pros: The people working here are some of the smartest and most interesting people I've met Lots of money and opportunities to learn Good vacation policy and work/life balance (for most folks)
cons: Look up "workplace cult" and Ocean Networks Canada ticks all the boxes. Sit down, don't ask questions, and if you do, they will find a way to get rid of you. They don't follow policies or procedures. Everything is reactive rather than proactive. If you aren't the perfect brown noser prepare to be bullied and have a miserable time at work. The union hates this organization. Upper management does whatever they want at the expense of the smart folks actually doing the work. Wasteful spending, stupid decision making, I've really never seen such incompetence at a workplace. Morale is horrible. It is such a shame because this could be the best place to work. They really don't care about science, it's all a facade. I worked here for 3 years and during that time I saw almost everyone I know quit/fired. I was actually a long term employee at the 3 year mark and that is disturbing. I hardly knew anyone near the end of my employment because I stopped making a point introducing myself to new hires, knowing that most of them won't even last a year.
Poor pay, inconvenient location to commute.

review_title: 2021 review of working at ONC in a term position
pros: Good benefits and pension in-accordance with UVic. I think depending on individual managers it will impact your work environment - the Learning engagement team for example has a supportive environment with a good team of people. We have managed to be continually productive during a pandemic and met many goals.
cons: Sometimes there is a lack of structure to projects and more work taken on than staff to complete. Communication between teams could be improve. Shorter term contracts are a pain because you never know (sometimes until the week before) if you are going to be extended - this is a HR, exec issue and funding issue and when you are on the other end it is stressful for life planning. Once you have had 3 years in a position you become full time ongoing but they then hire on 2-year terms often. Cons of pandemic working - we are working from home and there has been little support in setting up healthy ergonomic work from home offices - even when medical letters have been provided.

review_title: Stay away from this place if you value your career.
pros: Interesting project, nice team except for manager.  Laid back environment.  The campus is beautiful and has a lot of delicious and inexpensive food options. The university is a stimulating environment, intellectually.
cons:
The software team members (excluding management) have good potential for software development; and the overall environment at UVic is relatively relaxed compared to working at public companies where the deadlines can be very stressful.  

However, the talented employees are highly undervalued.  Not underpaid, undervalued. People who have left felt like they were not valued when they were there. Despite top-level efforts to curtail the negativity, there is a decidedly destructive political environment wherein people striving to do good work are not supported but are undermined and humiliated by unkind comments in public environments, punished by being ignored and passed over by management. 

There are unfortunately some people who are not the software developers themselves but whose role rhymes with tanager, who use bullying tactics rather than listening and setting a leadership example, in order to "win" arguments and ultimately get they want.  This is an unhealthy environment that can drag otherwise energetic and enthusiastic people down and eventually erode their careers.
